text:
City Hall Park: The old Hall of Records located at the S.W. corner of Park Row and Chambers Street. The structure was erected in 1735 as a debtors prison. During the Revolution it was used as a prison by the British. It was converted to its present status in 1840.

July 4, 1860

Gift of Urbrock Collection
American Studios
title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - Old Hall of Records.

text:
City Hall Park: The City Hall of New York City, erected 1812. The view is northward showing the entrance, wings and cupola.

About 1870

American Studios

title: Manhattan: City Hall Park -- City Hall

text:
City Hall Park: A view of the New York City Hall, when the Tweed Ring was building the County Court House. The wooden structure shown atop the latter was placed there, so that the public could not observe the slow progress being made. It cost the city $8,000,000 more than it should have; Tweed and his Ring taking the money.

About 1875?

Brown Bros.
title: Manhattan: City Hall Park.

text:
City Hall Park: A northeasterly view of the City Hall, showing the westerly and southerly sides of same. To the right is the old Brooklyn Bridge train shed over Park Row and to the left, the County Court House. Note the absence of the Pulitzer Building at the right. This was erected in 1889-90 on the site formerly occupied by French's Hotel. A clearance there evidently dates this view.
About 1889
Gift of W. A. Lucas
(2)
The Hall of Records in City Hall Park.
Photo by J.J.Corell  About 1900
From P.L.Sperr Collection

text:
City Hall Park: The old Hall of Records located at the S. W. corner of Park Row and Chambers Street. The "Tweed" County Court House is on the right. At the left is the pedestrian bridge across Park Row enabling persons to either cross or enter onto the Brooklyn Bridge promenade. The City Hall is just behind the Hall of Records and apparently mingled with several buildings on Broadway.

About 1900

Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Manhattan: Park Row - Chambers Street

text:

title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Armistice - [The peace celebration at City Hall Park.]

text:
City Hall Park: A view northward from the easterly side (Park Row at right) to show the distinctive Municipal Building at Chambers Street. Outlined against the lower portion of same is the Brooklyn Bridge extension and a Christmas tree. On the right and left margins respectively are, The City Hall and the Pulitzer (World) Building.

About 1920
title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [City Hall.]

text:
New York's most beautiful City Hall and its unique Municipal Building. A New photo showing two of the most famous buildings in New York - two buildings which visiting artists and architects invariably go to see. They go to see the exquisite old City Hall because it is a fine example of Colonial Architecture - and curiosity draws them to look at the unique Municipal Building, towering in the background one of the oddest bits of architecture in the history of America's many odd buildings. Behind the City Hall is the rear of the State Court.

10/22/1922
Underwood and Underwood
title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [Municipal Building.]

text:
(1)
City Hall Park: A rear view of the City Court, a brownstone structure erected in 1852 on the site of the Rotunda (built in 1816, where works of Art were exhibited). It was occupied by the Court of Special Sessions and in 1879 by the Tax Offices. In the early part of 1929 it was demolished. The Hall of Records, appearing on the right was wrected
in 1903.
November 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, obscuring the Hall of Records. Structure parti 1ly shown on
the right is the Municipal Building.
October 1928.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

text:
A general view of the lower East Side of Manhattan as photographed northeastward from the Woolworth Building (belief of the writer), showing that section east of Broadway (left) and north of the Brooklyn Bridge (right not included). In the foreground are several of the civic structures that surround City Hall Park. O'er cast by the shadow of the point of vantage are the roof of the old County Court House, the City Court, the Hall of Records, the Municipal Building, and the new hexagonal New York County Court House. The latter is under construction at this date and is the first civic structure to rise in the new center, Foley Square. Across the top runs the East River.

1923-4

Brown Bros., photo
title: General view - East side of Lower Manhattan.

text:
New York City: A remarkable view of upper downtown skyline from the Northeast showing how completely the Woolworth Building, 60 stories, 792 feet high, dominates its surroundings. At the extreme left is the tower of the Singer Building; alongside the Woolworth is the far less attractive Transportation Building. Far to the right is the New York Telephone Building. The old three cornered building is the old main post office and Federal Building, and the building in the foreground is the City Hall.
Sept. 1929
Ewing Galloway
title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [View of upper downtown skyline.]

text:
(1)&(2) City Hall Park and building in gala attire for reception of Amelia Earhart. Miss Earhart made an average speed record of 181.18 miles an hour over a measured 94 mile course, establishing the first women's international flight record on July 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr

title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - City Hall.

text:
The facade of City Hall with the buildings of lower Broadway behind it; people stroll beneath the trees of the park at left.

A Set of Seven Canvases of Old New Yor

These paintings come from a country house called 'Glencairn' near Dublin in Ireland, where they adorned the walls of the billiard room. The house was built by Richard 'Boss' Croker (1841-1922), an Irishman who for many years was associated with Tammany Hall in New York, holding political positions under William M. 'Boss' Tweed, and later, after the latter's ousting, under 'Honest John' Kelly. Following the Lexow Committee investigations (1889-90), he left for England where he took up residence in Wantage, Berks, returning to America periodically, attempting to regain his lost position in the Democratic Party. After his final defeat in 1900, he crossed the Atlantic once again, built 'Glencairn' and started a racing stable. Despite his past reputation (he paid, in all, $550,000 for his Irish estates), he lived up to the high standards demanded by British racing circles, and when his horse Orby won the Derby in 1907, did not even back him.

These pictures were painted to remind him of New York, and it is assumed that they were executed there around the turn of the century. All are painted in tones of sepia and green.

The British Government has recently acquired this mansion for the use of the British Ambassador to Ireland.

PARKE-BERNET
Sale 2234, Nov. 29-30, 1963
title: Manhattan: City Hall Park

text:
Dome of New York City's City Hall destroyed by fire. Photo shows the smoke pouring out of the dome while the firemen were attempting to put the fire out.

American Press Assn.
title: Manhattan: City Hall Park - [New York City Hall dome destroyed by fire.]
